## Course Aims

::: nonincremental
-   **Concepts:** Key terms like far-right, populism, radical right, and 'new nationalism'

-   **Analytical skills:** Different political and international dimensions of the far-right

-   **Theoretical tools:** Understanding current rise through comparative analysis across cases and time

-   **Critical thinking:** Assess theories explaining origins and persistence of far-right populism
:::

## Learning Outcomes

::: nonincremental
*By the end of this course you should be able to*:

-   Demonstrate a knowledge and understanding of the debates surrounding the contemporary far right in Europe and the ability to evaluate the different perspectives on the far right

# What's the problem?

```{r setup, include=FALSE}
# Load required packages
library(ggplot2)
library(plotly)
library(tidyverse)
library(haven)
library(htmltools)
library(ggthemes)

# Load data
cpds <- read_dta("data/CPDS_1960-2023_Update_2025.dta")

# Compute bloc-level totals
cpds <- cpds %>%
  rowwise() %>%
  mutate(
    far_right_total = sum(c_across(starts_with("right")), na.rm = TRUE),
    centre_right_total = sum(c_across(starts_with("conserv")), na.rm = TRUE),
    centre_left_total = sum(c_across(starts_with("social")), na.rm = TRUE)
  ) %>%
  ungroup()

# Create long format
cpds_long <- cpds %>%
  select(country, year, far_right_total, centre_right_total, centre_left_total) %>%
  pivot_longer(
    cols = c(far_right_total, centre_right_total, centre_left_total),
    names_to = "bloc",
    values_to = "vote_share"
  ) %>%
  mutate(
    bloc_label = case_when(
      bloc == "far_right_total" ~ "Far-Right",
      bloc == "centre_right_total" ~ "Centre-Right",
      bloc == "centre_left_total" ~ "Centre-Left"
    )
  )
```

## The Aggregate Picture

```{r}
#| echo: false
#| warning: false

# Calculate average far-right support by year
avg_support <- cpds_long %>%
  filter(bloc == "far_right_total", !is.na(vote_share)) %>%
  group_by(year) %>%
  summarise(
    avg_vote_share = mean(vote_share, na.rm = TRUE),
    n_countries = n()
  ) %>%
  filter(n_countries >= 5)  # Only years with at least 5 countries

# Create plot
p_avg <- ggplot(avg_support, aes(x = year, y = avg_vote_share)) +
  geom_line(size = 1.2, color = "black") +
  geom_point(size = 2, color = "black") +
  labs(
    x = "Year",
    y = "Average Vote Share (%)",
    title = "Average Far-Right Support Across Countries",
    subtitle = "Trend line shows overall pattern"
  ) +
  theme_solarized(base_size = 14) +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(face = "bold", size = 16),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(color = "gray40")
  )

ggplotly(p_avg, tooltip = c("x", "y")) %>%
  layout(hovermode = "x unified", autosize = FALSE, width = 900, height = 500)
```

::: notes
Notice the gradual increase, particularly from the 1980s onwards.
:::

## Exploring by Country

Click on country names in the legend to show/hide them. Double-click to isolate a single country.

```{r}
#| echo: false
#| warning: false

# Prepare far-right data by country
far_right_country <- cpds_long %>%
  filter(bloc == "far_right_total", !is.na(vote_share), vote_share > 0) %>%
  arrange(country, year)

# Calculate average across countries by year
far_right_avg <- far_right_country %>%
  group_by(year) %>%
  summarise(vote_share = mean(vote_share, na.rm = TRUE)) %>%
  mutate(country = "Average")

# Combine with country data
far_right_combined <- bind_rows(far_right_country, far_right_avg)

# Create the base plot
p_countries <- ggplot(far_right_combined, aes(x = year, y = vote_share, 
                                              color = country, group = country)) +
  geom_line(size = 1, alpha = 0.8) +
  geom_point(size = 1.5, alpha = 0.6) +
  scale_color_manual(
    values = c("Average" = "black", 
               setNames(scales::hue_pal()(length(unique(far_right_country$country))),
                       unique(far_right_country$country)))
  ) +
  labs(
    x = "Year",
    y = "Vote Share (%)",
    title = "Far-Right Support by Country",
    subtitle = "Click legend items to toggle countries"
  ) +
  theme_solarized(base_size = 14) +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(face = "bold", size = 16),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(color = "gray40"),
    legend.title = element_blank()
  )

# Convert to plotly and set visibility
p_interactive <- ggplotly(p_countries, tooltip = c("colour", "x", "y"))

# Set all traces except "Average" to be initially hidden
for (i in seq_along(p_interactive$x$data)) {
  if (p_interactive$x$data[[i]]$name != "Average") {
    p_interactive$x$data[[i]]$visible <- 'legendonly'
  }
}

p_interactive %>%
  layout(
    hovermode = "closest",
    legend = list(
      orientation = "v",
      x = 1.02,
      y = 1,
      title = list(text = "Country<br>(click to toggle)")
    )
  )
```

::: notes
Different countries show very different patterns. Some show steady growth, others show volatility.
:::

## Far-Right vs. Mainstream Parties

How does far-right growth compare to traditional political blocs?

```{r}
#| echo: false
#| warning: false

# Calculate average by bloc and year
bloc_comparison <- cpds_long %>%
  filter(!is.na(vote_share)) %>%
  group_by(year, bloc_label) %>%
  summarise(
    avg_vote_share = mean(vote_share, na.rm = TRUE),
    .groups = "drop"
  )

# Create comparison plot
p_comparison <- ggplot(bloc_comparison, aes(x = year, y = avg_vote_share, 
                                            color = bloc_label, group = bloc_label)) +
  geom_line(size = 1.3, alpha = 0.8) +
  geom_point(size = 2) +
  scale_color_manual(
    values = c("Far-Right" = "black", 
               "Centre-Right" = "#1f77b4", 
               "Centre-Left" = "red")
  ) +
  labs(
    x = "Year",
    y = "Average Vote Share (%)",
    title = "Political Bloc Comparison",
    subtitle = "Average support across countries",
    color = "Political Bloc"
  ) +
  theme_solarized(base_size = 14) +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(face = "bold", size = 16),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(color = "gray40"),
    legend.position = "bottom",
    legend.title = element_text(face = "bold")
  )

ggplotly(p_comparison, tooltip = c("colour", "x", "y")) %>%
  layout(
    hovermode = "x unified",
    legend = list(orientation = "h", x = 0.5, xanchor = "center", y = -0.2)
  )
```

::: notes
Notice the inverse relationship between far-right growth and centre-left decline in many periods.
:::

## The Unemplyment Puzzle

```{r}
#| echo: false
#| warning: false

avg_trends <- cpds %>%
  group_by(year) %>%
  summarise(
    mean_far_right = mean(far_right_total, na.rm = TRUE),
    mean_unemp = mean(unemp, na.rm = TRUE)
  )

ggplot(avg_trends, aes(x = year)) +
  geom_line(aes(y = mean_far_right), color = "black", size = 1) +
  geom_line(aes(y = mean_unemp / 2), color = "blue", size = 1, linetype = "dashed") +
  scale_y_continuous(
    name = "Average Far-Right Vote Share",
    sec.axis = sec_axis(~ . * 2, name = "Average Unemployment Rate (%)")
  ) +
  labs(
    x = "Year",
    title = "Average Far-Right Vote Share and Unemployment Over Time",
    subtitle = "Dashed blue line: unemployment rate (scaled for visibility)"
  ) +
  theme_solarized()
```

## Mudde's Framework: Three Core Features

```{mermaid}
%%{init: {'themeVariables': { 'fontSize': '24px', 'nodeSpacing': 60, 'rankSpacing': 60}}}%%
flowchart TB
A[Far-Right] --> B[Nativism]
A --> C[Authoritarianism]
A --> D[Populism]
```

**Key insight:** **Nativism** is the driving force for their policies

## Nativism: More Than Nationalism

-   **Nationalism:** The belief that political boundaries should align with national boundaries, and that the nation-state should be the primary source of political identity and sovereignty
-   **Nativism:** States should be inhabited **exclusively** by native group members
-   **"Non-natives" defined by:** Race, ethnicity, religion, or lifestyle (e.g., LGBTI+)
-   **Policy driver:** Immigration restriction, cultural protectionism, welfare chauvinism

## Authoritarianism: Order and Punishment

-   **Not anti-democratic:** Accept electoral democracy
-   **Social order:** Strictly hierarchical society
-   **Authority:** Strong adherence to in-group leaders
-   **Punishment:** Severe consequences for rule-breaking
-   **Traditional values:** Often religiously or culturally defined

## Populism: People vs Elite

-   **Core claim:** Society divided into "pure people" vs "corrupt elite"
-   **Democratic legitimacy:** "Will of the people" is morally superior
-   **Far-right populism:** People = in-group, Elite = those helping out-group
-   **Different from left populism:** Class exploitation vs cultural threat

## Is Far Right a homogenous party family?

```{r}
# Plot 1: Economic Position vs. GAL-TAN (Authoritarianism/Conservatism)
ches <- read_dta("/Users/cvrakopo/Downloads/1999-2024_CHES_dataset_means.dta")

library(tidyverse)
library(ggrepel)
library(ggthemes)

ches |>
  filter(family==1) |>
  mutate(eastwest = as_factor(eastwest)) |>
  group_by(party, eastwest) |>
  summarise(
    left_right_econ = mean(lrecon, na.rm=TRUE),
    galtan = mean(galtan, na.rm=TRUE),
    .groups = 'drop'
  ) |>
  ggplot(aes(x=left_right_econ, y=galtan, label=party, colour = eastwest)) +
  geom_point(size=3, alpha=0.7) +
  geom_text_repel(size=3) +
  labs(
    x="Economic Position (Left ← → Right)",
    y="Authoritarianism (Liberal ← → Traditional)",
    title="Plot 1: Economic Ideology Variation",
    subtitle="Far-right parties show economic heterogeneity",
    colour="Region"  # Clean up legend title
  ) +
  scale_color_manual(
    values=c("east"="#DC322F", "west"="#268BD2"),  # Solarized red/blue
    labels=c("east"="Eastern Europe", "west"="Western Europe")  # Nice names
  ) +
  theme_solarized(base_size=14) +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(face="bold"),
    legend.position = "bottom",  # Move legend below
    legend.title = element_text(face="bold", size=11)
  )
```

## Key Takeaways

-   Far-right support has **grown substantially** since the 1980s

-   The trend is **not uniform** across countries

-   This growth often coincides with **decline in traditional parties**

. . .

**Understanding these patterns is crucial for:**

-   Democratic resilience
-   Policy responses
-   Theoretical development in political science
